messages.content: Can you trace back the roots of your unique perspective on life, which includes elements of transcendence and mystery, to your early childhood in a quaint beach town not far from Manhattan? How did those beginnings plant the seeds for your view of life?

Well, I think being an only child is part of it. I had a lot of time on my own and I had very loving parents, but I spent a great deal of time alone in my room. And I read a lot and I got interested in magic, performing magic very early on. I was probably nine years old. And when you’re nine, doing a card trick or an actual miracle occurring — there’s gray area between that. The idea that there are things that we don’t understand when we see them and don’t make sense, and as a practicing magician, creating images that gave people the feeling that they were seeing something that they weren’t seeing, it blurred the line for me where reality begins and ends. And it’s still blurred.

Can you talk a bit about how your philosophy of supporting a myriad of life's possibilities has developed over the years, and how it has influenced your journey and creative life?

It has turned out that way. It’s really remarkable. It’s remarkable to watch because I don’t really know what I’m doing on any level, but I trust in what’s going on in my body and the feelings that come up. And I do my best to be as true to myself as I can be. And that’s all that I’ve ever done and it has led to a very creative life.

You have a unique talent for creating a supportive space for others, don't you? This is a communal act, and while it may be hard to explain, it likely stems from a genuine act of listening. Can you confirm this?
It seems, yes, it has happened. Again, it’s not anything I truly understand, but I think when you really listen to someone, they act differently. And most people are not used to being heard.
You have a unique ability to create environments where people feel listened to and understood on a communal level, correct?
It seems, yes, it has happened. Again, it’s not anything I truly understand, but I think when you really listen to someone, they act differently. And most people are not used to being heard.
Can you share your personal experiences that led you to learn about the music business during your college days, particularly your interactions with the 99 Records store?

Well, I didn’t know anything about the music business or how to do anything professionally. Just, I was in a punk rock band and I made recordings of my own band. And then I hung out in record stores because that’s where you could learn the most about music and get turned on to new things. And one of the record stores I hung out in was called 99 Records. And it was a tiny little shop on 99 McDougal. That’s where it was. And it was down a flight of stairs and it was a tiny little basement. Tiny. And I would go there and hear all this European music that I wouldn’t get to hear otherwise, not anything you would hear on the radio or not anywhere that you would hear unless you went to the coolest of nightclubs, you might hear this stuff. And I would hang out there. And they put out some of their own records that turned out to be really influential. And I would ask questions about how it was done. Because I spent so much time in the store, I was friends with the people who worked there. And they walked me through the process of where you could have vinyl pressed and where you could have covers manufactured, and where you could have labels made. And they were all in different places. And I would go from place to place and gather these things and then press up a few hundred copies of my punk rock band’s records. And I did that two times.
If asked to discuss the role and impact of music in our lives, based on your experiences over the years, how would you articulate it?

It seems to have a really therapeutic effect. I think we all want to be heard and music is a way to let out our inner emotional life, sometimes in a way that can’t necessarily be understood any other way. It functions different than prose or storytelling in that the music has an emotional base to it, even without the words. So you can feel this energy and express whatever’s going on inside of you through this form. And for young people, who have a lot of energy, it’s a great outlet, because you can channel all of the power of the energy that you have into, let’s say punk rock music, which was the case when I was a kid, or hip-hop music in the case of the things I got to work on. But it was definitely at the time, very young person’s music. And it was the music of people with a lot of energy and a lot of excitement about life and not really anywhere to put it. So this was a really positive place to put it.

What's your perspective on how every new generation consistently brings new forms and breathes life into different music genres, as seen in the evolution of hip-hop?

It’s true. It keeps happening over and over again. And I will tell you when it’s happening, it doesn’t seem like it’s happening. You know, at the time that we were making hip-hop records, there was no expectation that anybody would like what we were doing. We were making things on an artisanal level for ourselves and our friends. That’s it. The fact that it has taken on a life of its own is really shocking.

Reflect on how every generation continues to bring new forms of music to life. Often, while creating these new forms, the artists don't realize the impact that their work might eventually have, similar to the emergence of hip-hop.

It’s true. It keeps happening over and over again. And I will tell you when it’s happening, it doesn’t seem like it’s happening. I heard you've been working long-term on a literature project. Is this your first excursion into publishing authorship?

Indeed, this is my first venture into the realm of authorship. The process has spanned nearly a decade and I'm eagerly looking forward to presenting it to an audience. Understanding, exploring, and capturing the essence of the book's content has been a transformative, time-intensive journey - it's certainly not an aftermath of overnight wisdom.
I've caught wind of an ongoing endeavor you've been pouring time in. Is this your debut as an author, with this being your first ever publication?

Yes, this is my initial endeavor as an author. Everything about this journey, to write and prepare this book for publication, has been spread over seven to eight years. It's exciting to be on the verge of sharing it with the world. It's not just a collection of things I already knew, but an exploration that has demanded a great deal of time and patience.
And you have now been writing and you have now written a book. And is this your first book? You haven’t published a book before, have you?

This is my first book and I’ve been working on it for between seven and eight years now. And I, I’m so excited to finally get to share it with people because it’s been a long journey. And it was a long journey for me to get to understand what’s in the book because I can’t say that it’s things that I know.
Do you also write to discover your own thoughts and ideas, much like the enchanting mystery of creation itself?
Yes, that’s how it happened for me.

Can you elaborate on your statement that "The world is the doer and we are the witness. We have little or no control over the content"? It's a deeply profound sentiment that suggests our lives are largely influenced by external factors and that we are primarily observers.

Yes,  yes. It’s happening before us. We come in as a blank slate. We may have inclinations, I imagine. But what we take in over the course of our life is all that we’re filled with. So the world is going on and the creative life of the world is always happening. We get to watch it and if we choose to, we could participate. But if we don’t participate, it goes on.
Could you elaborate on your fascinating statement, "The world is the doer and we are the witness. We have little or no control over the content"?

Yes,  yes. It’s happening before us. We come in as a blank slate. We may have inclinations, I imagine. But what we take in over the course of our life is all that we’re filled with. Can one say that you tend to step into various paths or opportunities based solely on your visceral feelings and instincts, rather than on intellectual analysis or examination of data?

Yes. I think that’s, I think that’s realistic. I think that’s realistic. And it’s not intellectual, it’s not based on looking at any charts or any analysis. It’s only based on a feeling in me of what are the things that make me lean forward? What are the things that make me laugh? What are the things that make me excited? What do I find beautiful today that I didn’t notice yesterday? What are those things?
Can you describe your approach to decision making? Is it quite intuitive and centered on your feelings or reactions to new experiences, without much reliance on analysis or data?

Yes. I think that’s, I think that’s realistic. I think that’s realistic. And it’s not intellectual, it’s not based on looking at any charts or any analysis. It’s only based on a feeling in me of what are the things that make me lean forward? What are the things that make me laugh? What are the things that make me excited? What do I find beautiful today that I didn’t notice yesterday? What are those things?
Discussing the concept of nurturing creativity through intentional awareness, please share your thoughts on why the subtitle of your book is "A Way of Being".
Yes. And the reason the subtitle of the book is A Way of Being —
Could you elaborate on how intentional awareness contributes to nurturing one's creativity as they navigate through the world? This ties in with your book's subtitle 'A Way of Being', right?
Yes. And the reason the subtitle of the book is A Way of Being —
What do you usually do when you find yourself without any creative projects on hand?
It’s something I do. Sometimes I’ll visit, if I visit a friend in an office and I’ve never been to their office before, it’s not unusual for me to rearrange the furniture in the office.

Isn't there a delicate balance between managing creative projects and maintaining an open and playful spirit? Despite structuring our creative work with schedules and plans, doesn't the process of being creative necessitate a certain amount of flexibility and openness, which can sometimes be difficult to reconcile with these structures? You also mentioned the constant need to refresh awareness. How does this relate to our habits and rituals in a creative context?

Absolutely, understanding this relationship is vital. Remaining aware and receptive is a crucial practice in creative work. Simultaneously, developing good work habits is also necessary. It's interesting to note this dynamic, how everything we do is effectively a form of play, even when it may not feel like it.

It appears that the creative process involves some paradoxical elements, right? One the one hand, there's structure and discipline, and on the other, there's the essence of playfulness and an impulse to break away from rigid conventions. Besides, it seems you're suggesting that 'refreshing our awareness' lies at the heart of our habits and rituals. Is that correct?

Absolutely. Keeping ourselves attuned is essential, and that's where good habits come into play, irrespective of the inherent tension in our natural inclination towards play and the disciplined nature of planned activities.

Many of us hesitate to call those things creative. Or even — right? And then I think even when I say — I’m going to say those of us who have projects we call creative, right? Which is also fraught with self-doubt and wondering if it deserves that title. One of the things about more formal projects we’re calling creative is this interplay between openness and discipline, playfulness and structure. There’s all kinds of advice  about structure to create, about schedules. And the process of being creative and being open feels like it often stands in this terrible tension with all of that, right? I think you’re saying, with the getting things done. I think something in the way you came at this, that was, that just kind of shifts it is, because you said, “Awareness needs constant refreshing,” and that that in fact is the point of habits and rituals.

Absolutely. The practice of staying tuned in, that’s one of the practices. The other is the good work habits, which are — and it is, it’s funny, there’s a tension between the idea of everything we’re doing is playing, which it is.

Can you elaborate on how your experiences or realizations led you to understand the phases of working on something, from the seed phase to the final completion phase? You've mentioned in your book about struggling to finish projects; has this understanding impacted that tendency in any way?

But I’ll say that I learned something through the book, which is when I realized that not all of the four periods of work — so it starts with the seed phase is the first phase, and the second phase is the experimentation phase, the third phase is the craft phase, and the fourth phase is the final completion editing phase. And I’m a very good player  and was historically not a great finisher. It was always hard for me to finish projects.
What challenges do you face when trying to finish projects and how have you learned to manage them?

Yes, yes. It’s hard for me to finish projects because I always see the possibilities of what else we could try and I want to try everything, and I’m exhaustive, always, in what’s possible. So it’s hard for me to get things done. What I came to realize is that there is a time for this open play. And it’s in those first two parts of the process, the seed phase…

In your experience, why do you find it challenging to complete projects? Would you say it has something to do with being overwhelmed by the various possibilities? Could you discuss your process and how you manage this issue?

Yes, yes. It’s hard for me to finish projects because I always see the possibilities of what else we could try and I want to try everything, and I’m exhaustive, always, in what’s possible. So it’s hard for me to get things done. What I came to realize is that there is a time for this open play. And it’s in those first two parts of the process, the seed phase…
So, when you wrote the book, did it involve you revisiting many of your past professional experiences and reflections on the creative process?
Certainly, I had to wade through many memories and lessons learned over these years. The focus was very much on the understanding gained through these experiences.

It sounds like the book was more of an in-depth reflection on your lifelong journey engaging with the creative realm. Was it more or less an attempt to distil what you acquired along this personal and professional timeline, and then present it in a synthesized form?
It was exactly that. The goal was to encapsulate the information and knowledge accrued over years of diverse experiences, then breaking that down into something others could understand and use.

You know, I think it’s important to name here, when you talk about “what I learned from the book,” my understanding is that the process of writing all of this, of thinking it, of putting words around this was really about going back across your decades of working with the creative process of all kinds of different people, including your own and then kind of reverse engineering: “what did I learn about how this works?” Is that right?
Yes. That is right.
Can you explain how reading a book on work phases changed your perspective on having realistic expectations and schedules towards ending tasks or projects?

Yes. I realized through thinking of the phases of work as phases. Once I understood that, I never thought of it that way before. In the past, it was always: you start and you work until you’re done. And it has to be open-ended because that’s the only way you get to make anything good. So based on that, I realized, okay, we can start having really realistic expectations of ending things once we’ve gone through this process and we’ve done all of the open playing to the point where we have things that we love and we have a vision for the whole thing. And now it’s only a question of the final crafting, editing, and sharing that’s left. If we do that with a schedule, it’s actually helpful to the project. Whereas before I would think it would be, it would get in the way of it being all it could be. Now, I think getting on schedule at the right time in the process can be really helpful.

Yes. I realized through thinking of the phases of work as phases. Once I understood that, I never thought of it that way before. In the past, it was always: you start and you work until you’re done. And it has to be open-ended because that’s the only way you get to make anything good. And now it’s only a question of the final crafting, editing, and sharing that’s left. If we do that with a schedule, it’s actually helpful to the project. Whereas before I would think it would be, it would get in the way of it being all it could be. Now, I think getting on schedule at the right time in the process can be really helpful.

Given the complexity and unpredictability of human emotions and subconscious, and how you've been meticulous in noticing how memories and emotions can impact us, could you share your insights on the ways humans respond to stimuli and situations? I'm particularly interested in times when responses don't align with what's expected or when the feelings invoked by certain experiences aren't clear to us.

It’s all part of it. It’s all — we never know where it’s coming from. Sometimes we know if we’re responding directly to something that just happened, we know where it comes from. But often the way we respond to things don’t, it doesn’t always make sense. We might not know why something makes us feel a certain way. That happens — I tell a story in the book about watching, there was a documentary I was watching about AlphaGo.
Did you have any interest in doing that?
Yeah. And it was fascinating.
Did you find the experience interesting?
Yeah. And it was fascinating.
Could you describe the ancient board game of Go and its significance to the AI and programming community?

It’s — Go is an ancient game. It’s been played for 3000 years. It’s a board game like chess, but it has more possibilities. There are more possibilities in the game of Go than there are grains of sand on the planet. It’s the most difficult of all games in terms of predicting an outcome. And where we’ve had computer chess for some period of time, the idea of AI Go was a dream of the programming community and the AI community that would be a real benchmark. If the AI could play the game of Go as good or better than a grandmaster, that’d be a remarkable shift. And it was believed to be impossible.
Can you explain why you had an emotional reaction despite not caring whether the machine wins or man wins?

Yes. But I didn’t have that feeling at all. That’s not what it was. So I’m crying. It’s like, well I don’t care if the machine wins or man wins. Why am I having an emotional reaction? What’s going on? And I thought about it for, I think I realized what it was on the same day, but it was hours later. I was thinking about it for hours. Where is the emotion in this for me? Where’s the emotion? And eventually, it clicked.
Could you talk about your personal experience with meditation? How has it affected your perception of the world and your sense of self-awareness?

Certainly, my introduction to meditation at a young age allowed me to cultivate a certain way of viewing the world. It's as if one develops, for lack of a better term, an emotional strength, a state of presentness that is more attuned to the current experience. It's not about what the world is throwing at us, but focusing on a broader, more accepting and generous perspective. I'll liken it to curating, to distilling and selecting the most valuable aspects for ourselves, which we can then apply to personal and professional spheres of our life.
Can you delve more into the concept of evolving the way we see our lives through practices such as meditation? How exactly does that work, from your perspective?

Absolutely, evolving the way we see our lives can be greatly influenced by practices like meditation. Meditation is instrumental in forming an inner reality that's new and enhancing emotional resilience. It brings a heightened sense of being in the present, of experiencing the moment. It’s a way to filter out the noise, to open up to a wider, more generous perspective... It’s challenging to accurately describe it, but it’s akin to being your own curator, discerning the best parts and using them to better our lives and our work.

I want to kind of come to some of the very concrete and available practices that you offer, just to have a practice of awareness towards that state you’re talking about which somewhere you say the, it’s about learning “to learn and be fascinated and surprised on a continual basis.” And of course meditation. But also, a day walking in nature. I don’t know, you’ve talked about before you go to sleep “noticing the feelings of your heartbeat and the movement of your blood.” And you said, “The purpose of such exercises is not necessarily in the doing, just as the goal of meditation isn’t in the meditating. The purpose is to evolve the way we see the world when we’re not engaged in these acts.”

Yes, and by learning to meditate when I was young and having that practice — and it’s the nature of meditation— your life off the cushion changes. And it changes because you’re building a new reality within yourself. A new, I’ll call it like an emotional musculature, that is more in tune with the present as you are experiencing it in this moment. And not the distractions that the world is bombarding us with, but a wider, more open, more generous … I don’t know how to say it. I guess we’ll go back to the curation. Just being able to see more and curate the best of it for ourselves to be able to then use both in our lives and in our work.
What could be the results of truly immersing ourselves in nature, and disregarding what we’ve been conditioned to believe or behave by society?
Well, exactly. You know, breaking free of societal norms, thinking for ourselves, existing purely in the moment. Embracing what's beautiful, what's wild.
Isn't it a bit like freeing ourselves from constructed norms and appreciating the inherent beauty of the world we live in?
Yes, indeed. It’s about letting go of preconceived notions and experiencing nature in its raw and undiluted state. It's about loosening up, you know? Becoming free.
Here’s a really striking sentence also: “The beauty around us … is an end in itself.” Right? All of this stands in a contrast to a lot of the ways we’re conditioned, right?
Yes. Yeah. getting out of our own heads. Getting out of what we were told, you know? Getting out of what we were taught. Being free.
Was he considered one of the greatest college basketball coaches ever, possessing the most wins in history at the college-level?
Yes. He was the greatest college basketball coach in history. The most winning coach in history. And this is college-level.
Could you share your thoughts on the importance of teaching children basic tasks like putting on their socks or tying their shoelaces, emphasizing the significance of details in every task?

Yeah. How to put their socks on properly and how to properly tie their, lace up and tie their shoes. You know it’s so — And it would be like a kindergarten class. But his point was that every detail matters. And it’s not the best way to do the extreme version of what you’re doing, it’s how you do every step, every piece leading up to it. All of the practices involved.
Can you explain how to correctly put on socks and shoes, emphasizing the importance of mastering every step in the process, similar to how detailed one can be in a kindergarten class?

Yeah. How to put their socks on properly and how to properly tie their, lace up and tie their shoes. You know it’s so — And it would be like a kindergarten class. But his point was that every detail matters. And it’s not the best way to do the extreme version of what you’re doing, it’s how you do every step, every piece leading up to it. All of the practices involved.
What insights can you share about your approach to handling challenges or failures?

It’s helpful to think in terms of: it’s only play. We’re here to play. We’re here to have fun. And to use the feedback of, you know, sometimes failure is the thing you need to know to get to where you’re going. So if you try to solve a problem 10 ways and they all fail, you can either decide I’m a failure or you can decide, okay, I’m now 10 methods closer to finding the solution because I’ve ruled out those 10. And that really is our work is we’re constantly ruling things out. We’re trying things with no expectation.
How have you adjusted your mindset when handling failures and finding solutions?

It’s helpful to think in terms of: it’s only play. We’re here to play. We’re here to have fun. And to use the feedback of, you know, sometimes failure is the thing you need to know to get to where you’re going. So if you try to solve a problem 10 ways and they all fail, you can either decide I’m a failure or you can decide, okay, I’m now 10 methods closer to finding the solution because I’ve ruled out those 10. And that really is our work is we’re constantly ruling things out. We’re trying things with no expectation.
What advice would you give to someone who is feeling anxious or unnerved about improving their writing skills?

Yes, absolutely. One thing I would suggest, hearing that story, I would suggest write as much as you can and don’t look back at it. Just write. And at some point down the road, after you’ve done a lot of writing , then go back and start reading it. Hopefully by the time you forgot what you’ve written.
How has therapy influenced your understanding of memories and experiences?

It's been immensely influential. I've been through extensive therapy, and it's taught me a lot about my own ways of thinking and remembering. As a sensitive individual, I've found that my experiences sometimes takes on an emotional depth that someone less sensitive might not comprehend.
How does your sensitivity impact your work with artists?

Being highly sensitive means I tend to connect with artists on a deeper level. We often share a mutual understanding and experience emotions more intensively. This can sometimes lead to a kind of resonance, which can be both beautiful and challenging.

…can get out of control. And you end up working absolutely very intentionally. And here’s some things you wrote that just were really helpful to me about, you know, you were talking about memories. Because they’re with us and they become raw materials, but you said “Memories can  be thought of as dream-like.” Because in fact, they are “more a romantic story than a faithful document of a life event.”

Yes, and I’ve done a lot of work on myself therapy-wise and had a lot of help and studied a lot. And I’m a very sensitive person. So one of the things that I get by working with sensitive artists, we resonate together in that we’re feeling things that not everybody else is feeling. And they could be very painful. And for someone who’s less sensitive can view how we’re feeling it as, oh, they’re — they don’t understand.

In describing how you prepared him for his podcast, you mentioned having him watch a Marshall Rosenberg video about non-violent communication - something others might not typically associate with creating a record. Can you share more about why that was part of your process?

No, it was unusual.  It’s not standard. But it’s standard in the way that — the way that I get to work with artists is like we’re friends hanging out and talking about whatever comes up. And through that, things get unlocked that allow writing and performances to be more closer to the core. And that’s the goal with all of this.
How has this experience influenced your perspectives, especially in relation to your creative life?
I’ll say, it’s just really fun. I don’t know yet — at this point, I can’t tell you how it interacts with my creative life, but I’ll say it’s really fun and he gets so enthusiastic about things.
Can you share how this particular experience has influenced your overall view and its relationship with your creativity?
I’ll say, it’s just really fun. I don’t know yet — at this point, I can’t tell you how it interacts with my creative life, but I’ll say it’s really fun and he gets so enthusiastic about things.
Isn't it amazing to remain open and curious, much like a child who is fascinated by everything around them? They seem to have a different relationship with time, don't they?

Yes. And the image of the child walking and picking up everything that they see that’s interesting to them or wanting to stop and look at it, is beautiful. And I think what patience is really about is our relationship to time. And I think a child’s relationship to time is much more rooted in reality. I think we have a…

So, it's crucial to remember that the natural beauty around us is not a burden to take care of, but a pleasure to enjoy, right? Is this what defines the way we interact with it and directly impacts our quality of life?

Indeed. For instance, choosing to observe the sunrise each day can be very enlightening. To see its similarity and variance each day, and promising ourselves that we'll make an effort to be somewhere where we can watch the sunrise every day. It's a worthy practice. And there's no shortage of other practices like this one.
It seems like it's not just about appreciating the beauty but committing to it as a regular practice, like watching the changing hues of the sky every day, would that be a fulfilling practice?

Absolutely. Engaging in a unique practice like observing the moonrise every day can be fulfilling. Notice its slight variations and consistencies. We should make a pledge that wherever we are, we'll have time to witness the moonrise every day. This can be quite invigorating. And there's a whole array of practices like this one to delve into.

Yeah.  And I think maybe the point, or just not a point, but a byproduct of understanding that the core discipline is constantly refreshing awareness that “the beauty around us … is an end in itself” — I’m quoting you — is that, that is not labor, right? How we orient ourselves to this is what matters, is what makes it life-giving.

Absolutely. And if we pick a practice like deciding we’re going to watch the sunset every day, that’s a beautiful practice. How is it similar day-to-day? How is it different day-to-day? Making the commitment that we’re going to put ourselves in a place where we can see the sun setting every day. It’s a beautiful practice. What do you think about the notion that "Not all projects take time, but they do take a lifetime"? It's a mysterious concept suggesting that we embody everything we've learned and done into our creations. Do you agree with this perspective on creativity?

Yes. And that speaks to the fact that everything we make is the sum total of everything we’ve learned and done. We’re not — our creativity doesn’t come from our ideas. All of everything in us comes from somewhere else. And we get to take those elements, and I think I use the word in the book, re-present. We have this information, and we get it, and we get to mix it up and reform it and re-present it back to the world.
